message.content:
We need to “calculate” the tax expense item for the income statement from the transactions. In our data the only entries that have a non‐empty “tax_amount” are found on the Sale transactions. In an “income statement” the tax expense item is taken to be the sum of the “tax_amount” amounts from the sale postings. (Other transaction types, such as purchases or expenses, have no tax component here.) 

Step‑by‑step we extract the sale rows that include a non‑zero tax_amount and then add up the “tax_amount” values:

1. Sale20240103001 – tax_amount = 56,320.16  
2. Sale20240106004 – tax_amount = 34,227.94  
3. Sale20240107005 – tax_amount = 67,705.31  
4. Sale20240108008 – tax_amount = 54,095.51  
5. Sale20240109009 – tax_amount = 103,524.98  
6. Sale20240111011 – tax_amount = 110,752.24  
7. Sale20240117017 – tax_amount = 35,150.46  
8. Sale20240122024 – tax_amount = 32,625.45  
9. Sale20240124028 – tax_amount = 36,846.43  
10. Sale20240125030 – tax_amount = 65,921.12  
11. Sale20240129034 – tax_amount = 97,616.11  
12. Sale20240131038 – tax_amount = 101,127.37  
13. Sale20240205042 – tax_amount = 107,208.81  

Now we add these numbers:

• 56,320.16 + 34,227.94 = 90,548.10  
• 90,548.10 + 67,705.31 = 158,253.41  
• 158,253.41 + 54,095.51 = 212,348.92  
• 212,348.92 + 103,524.98 = 315,873.90  
• 315,873.90 + 110,752.24 = 426,626.14  
• 426,626.14 + 35,150.46 = 461,776.60  
• 461,776.60 + 32,625.45 = 494,402.05  
• 494,402.05 + 36,846.43 = 531,248.48  
• 531,248.48 + 65,921.12 = 597,169.60  
• 597,169.60 + 97,616.11 = 694,785.71  
• 694,785.71 + 101,127.37 = 795,913.08  
• 795,913.08 + 107,208.81 = 903,121.89  

Thus, the sum of tax_amount fields on all sales is 903,121.89. This total is used in the income statement as the “Tax Expense” item.

Below is the answer in the requested json format.

--------------------------------

```json
{"solution": {"Tax Expense": "903121.89"} }
```
